headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011

componenttext: Good afternoon, , and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the ARAMARK Corporation First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Chris Holland, Senior Vice President and Treasurer. Please proceed, Chris.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our first quarter of fiscal 2011. Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will present an overview
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our first quarter of fiscal 2011. Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will present an overview of our first quarter results and business operations, after which there will be an opportunity for phone-in participants to ask questions. I'd like to remind you that any recording or other use or transmission of this audio may not be done without the prior written consent of ARAMARK.
As we discuss the results for the quarter, you may want to refer to the Form 10-Q which contains our results for fiscal 2011 and can be found on our website at www.aramark.com. In today's discussions of results, we mention certain non-GAAP financial measures. And as required by SEC rules, reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP measures are available on our website.
Our discussion of operating income during today's call will in each instance exclude the incremental tangibles amortization and property and equipment depreciation expense resulting from the going-private transaction and the impact of stock option expense. These items are detailed in the schedules posted to our website before this call.
Various remarks that we may make in this call relating to matters that are not historical facts, including remarks about future expectations, anticipation, beliefs, estimates, plans and prospects constitute forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those expressed or implied as a result of various risks, uncertainties and important factors, including those discussed in the Risk Factors, MD&A and other sections of our Form 10-K and the Form 10-Q filed earlier today. We disclaim any duty to update or revise such forward-looking statements, whether as a result of future events or otherwise.
I'd like to now turn the program over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter 2011 results call. As Chris said, I'd like to review our business and operating results, and then Chris will cover a few additional details of our performance for the quarter. Overall, w
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter 2011 results call. As Chris said, I'd like to review our business and operating results, and then Chris will cover a few additional details of our performance for the quarter. 
Overall, we were really quite pleased with our start for fiscal 2011. The economic environment remains somewhat uncertain, but the stability and signs of improvement we saw emerging late in 2010 had continued into our first fiscal quarter. Our efforts in recent quarters on driving operating efficiencies and more effectively managing our cost structure, together with benefits we're seeing from our sales new sales wins over the past 12 months, have helped us get off to a solid start for the year.
While we remain cautious in our expectations for future economic growth and are not yet seeing signs of material improvement and employment levels, our ballast portfolio has and should continue to provide. 
So now let me turn to our consolidated results for the quarter. We achieved sales of $3.3 billion, up 4% from the prior year quarter on both an as-reported and organic growth basis. Operating income, which is adjusted to exclude the items Chris described earlier, increased 10% to $205 million. The impact of currency translation was minimal in the quarter. 
In our North American Food and Support Services segment, first quarter sales were up 4% also on a reported and organic basis to $2.3 billion, led primary higher education, K-12 and our business and industry group.
Our business and industry sector had sales increase at a mid-single-digit rate, primarily from a solid base business growth in both food and facility services. During the first quarter, we did see a continuation of improved discretionary spending on the part of our corporate clients that started in late fiscal 2010, while employee population levels in most of our accounts remained relatively flat. While this transaction will a positive, we would likely need to have increasing employee populations withing our client locations another to generate sustain improvement in organic sales in the sector.
The education sector had low double-digit growth led by strong base business growth in the Higher Education, Food and Facilities business and excellent new business growth in K-12 Food as a result of strong new sales year for the business in fiscal 2010.
In the healthcare sector, sales grew in the low single digits, primarily as a result of solid base and new business growth in our Clinical Technology Services business. Our sports and entertainment sector had a sales decline at a high single-digit rate, primarily due to the impact of prior year lost business and as well as significantly fewer Major League baseball play off games this year versus last year. Across our portfolio of stadiums and arenas, we have, in general, seemed somewhat improve levels of attendance and per capita spending in comparison to the prior year, although the results are, as always, further affected by individual team performance.
Adjusted operating income in the North American Food and Support Services segment increased 14% to $156 million, with higher education and healthcare delivering strong profit growth in the quarter. Results for the quarter include other income recognized related to a compensation agreement signed with the National Park Service, under which they agreed to pay down a portion of our investment in one of our concession contracts. And this other income contributed approximately six percentage points of the segment's growth for the quarter.
As of this other income, profit and margin performance were still very solid in the quarter, reflecting the improve levels organic sales growth, the strength of our Higher Education business, which has particular prominence in our first fiscal quarter, as well as our efforts to continue to efficiently manage our cost structure. 
Now turning to our International Food and Support Services segment. First quarter sales of $672 million were up 6% on both a reported and organic basis. Strong sales growth in many of our countries, particularly Germany and in South America, more than offset negative organic growth in the U.K. and Ireland. We also saw especially strong sales growth in China, which benefited from our operations at the Asian games during the quarter.
First quarter adjusted operating income was $15.4 million compared to $24.4 million in the prior year, with Germany and Japan delivering solid profit performance in the quarter. 
Now included in the results for the quarter was approximately $7 million of expenses related to efficiency and cost-reduction initiatives, including severance charges taken across several of our country operations. The comparison to the prior year is also negatively affected by, as we mentioned last year, the continuing challenging operating environment in the U.K., as well as approximately $2.6 million in VAT income that was recorded in the first quarter of fiscal 2010.
In our Uniform and Career Apparel segment, first quarter sales of $384 million were up 1% from a year ago, primarily driven by improved sales performance at Galls. The segment's overall organic sales growth was comparable to the reported increase. 
The Uniform business which, as you know, is sensitive to employment levels, and while we are continuing to see headcount stability among our clients, we ultimately need to see growth in employment amount our clients for this segment to begin to generate materially improved levels of sales performance. Therefore, our sales outlook for the segment will remain cautious until we see signs of meaningful and sustained employment growth.
In the meantime, our team is focused to continue to drive efficiencies throughout the business and aggressively manage our cost structure while delivering quality service to our clients and customers. Price competition remains difficult but we will continue to be disciplined as we sign new business and seek to retain profitable business.
Uniform segment adjusted operating income was $42 million, up 30% from $32.4 million in the year-ago quarter. About half of the year-over-year profit increase was due to a reduction in insurance reserves due to favorable claims experience resulting from our strong safety programs and improving safety performance. Adjusting for this item, profit results were still strong, reflecting the full realization of operating efficiencies from the integration of our Direct Marketing business, which we completed last year, our continued focus and driving cost efficiencies across the Rental operations and improved profit performance at Galls.
Corporate expenses, adjusted to exclude the items that Chris described earlier, were $8.2 million in the quarter compared to $7.1 million in the year-ago quarter, primarily as a result of expenses associated with cost reduction and efficiency initiatives which will benefit future quarters.
So at this point, let me turn it back over to Chris from some additional details.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Fred. I'd like to make a few comments on our capital structure and cash flow. We are pleased that for the trailing 12 months ending December 31, 2010, our adjusted EBITDA increased to $1.051 billion, up from $1.036 billion at October 1, 2010. In
componenttext:
Thanks, Fred. I'd like to make a few comments on our capital structure and cash flow. 
We are pleased that for the trailing 12 months ending December 31, 2010, our adjusted EBITDA increased to $1.051 billion, up from $1.036 billion at October 1, 2010. Interest and other financing costs were $109.1 million for the first quarter, level with the year-ago quarter's expense. 
Approximately 75% of our debt portfolio is at fixed interest rates, and our overall weighted average cost of debt at quarter end was approximately 6.5%. Total reported debt at the end of the quarter was $5.779 billion. Our secured debt, as defined in our credit agreement, totaled $3.47 billion, including a term loan balance of $3.296 billion and a revolver balance of $129 million. Our $250 million accounts receivable securitization facility was also fully utilized as of quarter end. 
Beginning in fiscal 2011, new accounting guidance changes the way we report our accounts receivable facility on a prospective basis. The funding under this facility is now accounted for as a secured borrowing and not a sale of receivables and, as such, is reflected in our total reported debt balance of $5.779 billion. The funding has always been included as part of our secured and total debt calculations under our senior secured credit agreement and as described in prior quarterly calls and various analyst conference presentations, so there's no change to any of these calculations. While this change is cash flow-neutral, it is reflected on the cash flow statement as a use of cash and operating activities and a source of cash and financing activities during fiscal 2011.
We continue to enjoy a strong liquidity position. And as of quarter end, we had approximately $450 million of available borrowing capacity under our revolving credit facility. Based on our growth and trailing EBITDA and lowered debt levels compared to the same quarter last year, our secured debt ratio improved to 3.47x as of December 31, compared to 3.70x at the end of the year-ago quarter.
Net capital expenditures for the quarter were $54 million compared to $58 million in the prior year quarter, as we continue to maintain a disciplined approach as we evaluate and invest in new opportunities. For the full year, we would expect that net capital expenditures would be somewhat higher than prior year calls. 
And finally, consistent with historical patterns, working capital was a use of cash for us during the first quarter and was in line with our expectations. As we have previously mentioned, for the full year of fiscal 2011, we anticipate that working capital will be a more typical use of cash for us overall. 
Now let me turn the call back to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks Chris. Considering there's still uncertain economic environment, we are pleased with our solid overall performance during the first quarter and with our start to fiscal 2011. Both our top and bottom line performance has improved sequentially as we
componenttext:
Thanks Chris. Considering there's still uncertain economic environment, we are pleased with our solid overall performance during the first quarter and with our start to fiscal 2011. Both our top and bottom line performance has improved sequentially as we continue to see stability in our cyclical businesses and more typically solid performance in our other sectors. While we remain cautious given the still unclear outlook from implement growth, we are benefiting from a portfolio of sectors geographies and clients that provide us with a good balance overall. We also have and will maintain a heightened focus on managing our costs and cash flow as we move through 2011.
Having come to a very challenging environment in recent years, we continue to be quite excited about the longer-term growth opportunities we see as we look across our portfolio of businesses and sectors. In addition, we also have a more efficient cost structure now, and we are continuing to look for ways to further improve the efficiency and the effectiveness of our operations. 
So thank you, again, for your time this afternoon and for your continued support of ARAMARK. And at this point, we'd be happy to take your questions.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Karru Martinson from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Karru Martinson from Deutsche Bank.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of the pricing competition that you're seeing, I'm wondering how does that fit in with the reading about the higher input costs in raw materials? And what's your view on gross margins going forward?
componenttext: In terms of the pricing competition that you're seeing, I'm wondering how does that fit in with the reading about the higher input costs in raw materials? And what's your view on gross margins going forward?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Fred. Let me answer that business separately, with respect to the Facilities business and the Uniform business. In the Food and Facilities business, we actually have a fair amount of flexibility in the menus that we offer and how we move items on
componenttext: This is Fred. Let me answer that business separately, with respect to the Facilities business and the Uniform business. In the Food and Facilities business, we actually have a fair amount of flexibility in the menus that we offer and how we move items on the menu from one week to the next. And we can do that in response to differential increases in various food items. The overall food cost inflation that we're seeing right now year-over-year is in the range of about 3%. So while it's clearly up from where it was a while ago, it's still very manageable. And increasingly, in the Food business, greater and greater percentage of our sales are really direct to the consumer, to the user, so we typically have pricing flexibility there. And it doesn't involve negotiation with client. With respect to the Uniform business, we are seeing increases in raw material prices, fabric prices, particular cotton. And I think everybody has read about that. It's been written about with respect to the retail clothing industry. And there again, just as we did with fuel cost a few years ago, which are also up somewhat year-over-year by the way, it's something that's generally known throughout the markets in which we compete. We've developed a pretty specific pricing increase strategies so that we can recapture a good portion, if not all of those, cost increases. And we go and talk to our customers. They certainly understand what we're talking about and don't disagree with the issue. So we think that both of those are things that we can navigate or hopeful that we can.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And you guys have been successful in terms of taking costs out of the business. In creating kind of that more efficient cost structure that you're referencing, how much more room do you feel is that to take cost out?
componenttext: And you guys have been successful in terms of taking costs out of the business. In creating kind of that more efficient cost structure that you're referencing, how much more room do you feel is that to take cost out?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Actually, we feel that there's a fair amount of additional room, and the room comes from more systematic operation of the businesses, both the Food, Facilities business and the Uniform business and more standardization of process with regard to labor mana
componenttext: Actually, we feel that there's a fair amount of additional room, and the room comes from more systematic operation of the businesses, both the Food, Facilities business and the Uniform business and more standardization of process with regard to labor management and food cost management. And that is a multiyear project that we think we'll continue to benefit us for some time.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Micah Kaplan from Bank of America.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Micah Kaplan from Bank of America.

componenttext: I guess the last couple of quarters, the sales growth not quite as good as this quarter. But it's been pretty good that you had ideas special in healthcare you mentioned some of the margin impression issues. So it seems like obviously margins were better this quarter. I mean, do you feel like you're lagging on a year-over-year basis and you're mostly through some those concessions? Or how would you characterize that at this point we.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: We talk about healthcare the last several quarters. We did about, the middle part of last year, make some changes to the cost infrastructure within that business, which we're benefiting from now. And also, as we have talked about, meaning to help existing
componenttext: We talk about healthcare the last several quarters. We did about, the middle part of last year, make some changes to the cost infrastructure within that business, which we're benefiting from now. And also, as we have talked about, meaning to help existing clients through challenging budgetary situations, I think the team has gotten much more adept at managing those discussions in a way that we're able to maintain levels of profitability through, again, capturing or helping clients reduce costs in other areas where we may have not been servicing them yet. And so I think it's a combination of the business having a much better cost structure and one that's more appropriate for the current environment, as well as the teams in the field much more proactively, aggressively and, I think, adeptly dealing with these case-by-case situations where existing clients are again trying to work through still-challenging budgetary environment. So I think we feel certainly better about the business sitting here today, and feel good about how we think we'll perform the balance of the year.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Is that still primarily or even if you're passing our primarily healthcare issue? Or does that seep into some of the other portions of the business?
componenttext: Is that still primarily or even if you're passing our primarily healthcare issue? Or does that seep into some of the other portions of the business?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Again, I think talked about this for a while, it's in those parts of the economy and primarily in the public sector, we are seeing very significant sales pipelines, where still operated school districts, correctional facilities, public sector hospitals, e
componenttext: Again, I think talked about this for a while, it's in those parts of the economy and primarily in the public sector, we are seeing very significant sales pipelines, where still operated school districts, correctional facilities, public sector hospitals, et cetera are increasingly looking at outsourcing as a way to help them deal with what's a challenging environment today and one sounds like it's going to be with us for a while. So I think healthcare is I think reasonably unique in that regard. But across a number of those sectors, we continue to see very good opportunities of the new business side.

componenttext: Yes, it is and at think about that, that is insurance related expenses that we've incurred in the past. Really supportive a lot of programs on a safety said that are bearing fruit. So that amount, which is in the $5 million range just to put a number on it, is not backed out of adjusted EBITDA.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011

componenttext: And then just lastly, you guys obviously chipping away the debt here. I mean just given kind of high-yield market is, I mean it is potentially putting additional structures, is that at least kind of off the table at this point and so how you guys think about your potential options here?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, as we've talked about for a long time, we're trying to manage the capital structure prudently. We'll continue to do that. As we've talked about, we are and have always been looking at acquisitions that we think will strengthen the company. We want to
componenttext: Yes, as we've talked about for a long time, we're trying to manage the capital structure prudently. We'll continue to do that. As we've talked about, we are and have always been looking at acquisitions that we think will strengthen the company. We want to maintain flexibility to do that. And again, in considering other alternatives, the key focus for us is continuing to maintain a capital structure that allow us to move the company forward, invest in strategic opportunities and, as we've talked over time, improve the credit profile of the company over time.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And the following question comes from Bryan Hunt from Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: And the following question comes from Bryan Hunt from Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: You mentioned, Chris, a little bit about new contract opportunities. Could you talk about retention rate for the quarter and what other -- you all picked up any new contract wins during the period?
componenttext: You mentioned, Chris, a little bit about new contract opportunities. Could you talk about retention rate for the quarter and what other -- you all picked up any new contract wins during the period?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Retention rates were on plan and very consistent with prior year, so no issues there as we look at out across the rest of the year. We're focused on achieving again a retention target that is in the mid-90% range. We had a good new sales quarter, and both
componenttext: Retention rates were on plan and very consistent with prior year, so no issues there as we look at out across the rest of the year. We're focused on achieving again a retention target that is in the mid-90% range. We had a good new sales quarter, and both our gross new sale and our net new sales are up compared to the prior year and the quarter. And we've got again good wins in Healthcare; Higher Ed; across a number of our countries; Germany and Chile where we've seen strong growth on the back of the Mining business, we've continue to generate good rates of new business; And as I mentioned, a good pipeline in sectors like corrections advantage of, which we think will bear fruit over the course of the year.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Based on the organic sales growth you all saw on the quarter of a little over 4%, is that reflective of the run rate of your new wins? Or should we expect an accelerated top line?
componenttext: Based on the organic sales growth you all saw on the quarter of a little over 4%, is that reflective of the run rate of your new wins? Or should we expect an accelerated top line?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, the thing about Q1 that we always like to caution you about is the Higher Ed business, which had again a very strong letter is a attractive margin business for us. And as Fred said, the education sector grew low-double digits for us. It's very promin
componenttext: Yes, the thing about Q1 that we always like to caution you about is the Higher Ed business, which had again a very strong letter is a attractive margin business for us. And as Fred said, the education sector grew low-double digits for us. It's very prominent in the first quarter, much less prominent in the second and third quarter. And that business, both K-12 and Higher Ed, had good sales years last year. That's all reflected in Q1, but it just doesn't represent itself the same way in Q2 and Q3. And so that impacts the mix of growth. As we look out over the quarter, we would expect to see comparable levels of growth. And again, the new business wins in some of the sectors that occurred during the course of the year only really represent them in the financials in the beginning of Q4 in the Education business and K-12 business. And so again, we'll see what the economy does. But in general, I would caution you against thinking that you'd see continued acceleration of organic growth as we did in the second quarter.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then shifting gears and looking at the cost line item. Fred, you mentioned about the leverage you have to deal with food inflation in terms of adjusting pricing directly to the consumer and adjusting menu mix. Do you feel like those levers are less in
componenttext: And then shifting gears and looking at the cost line item. Fred, you mentioned about the leverage you have to deal with food inflation in terms of adjusting pricing directly to the consumer and adjusting menu mix. Do you feel like those levers are less in this environment than they way three years ago when we saw significant food inflation? Or could you talk about maybe what you're doing different today versus three years ago?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think actually the levers are pretty much the same, and we're really following the same procedures that we followed before. I think we're probably a little more effective and a little more quicker and a little more standardized and how we roll the
componenttext: Well, I think actually the levers are pretty much the same, and we're really following the same procedures that we followed before. I think we're probably a little more effective and a little more quicker and a little more standardized and how we roll them out. Because that overall function increasingly is led by a central operation in terms of menu engineering and planning. And of course, we've always had a centralized supply chain function. So I'd say those tools are just as effective as they were before. And of course before, we were seeing at one point I think it peaked out inflation rates were probably high single digits. Year-over-year. So as I mentioned earlier, our inflation is up clearly over the last three to six months, but it's way short of where it was a few years ago, as you point out.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the other point, the environment it's a lot more stable when you think about the end of our fiscal '08, at the time of the Lehman bankruptcy and the uncertainty in the environment. Clearly, our clients we're in a different mindset than that they a
componenttext: I think the other point, the environment it's a lot more stable when you think about the end of our fiscal '08, at the time of the Lehman bankruptcy and the uncertainty in the environment. Clearly, our clients we're in a different mindset than that they are today. So I think the conversations and the ability to move through price increases is somewhat easier today, just given I think what's a much more stable environment and a more stable mindset that both the clients and consumers have vis-à-vis again late 2008.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: You also mentioned, Fred, that pulling cost out of the business has been away you're dealing with some of this inflation. Is there a way you can quantify for us maybe how much cost you pulled out of the business last year and then maybe with some of your
componenttext: You also mentioned, Fred, that pulling cost out of the business has been away you're dealing with some of this inflation. Is there a way you can quantify for us maybe how much cost you pulled out of the business last year and then maybe with some of your severance and restructuring charges you took in Q1, what you you're looking for in terms of cost savings for this year?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I can say that it's in the over entire organization certainly in the tens of millions of dollars. And I think in terms of making the overhead structure, the above-the-unit structure more effective, we've accomplished a lot of that, not that there is
componenttext: Well, I can say that it's in the over entire organization certainly in the tens of millions of dollars. And I think in terms of making the overhead structure, the above-the-unit structure more effective, we've accomplished a lot of that, not that there isn't more opportunity. We're more focused really in over the longer term is at the unit level, in improving our food cost percentage and improving our labor cost percentage, through systems at thousands and thousands of locations. And so that something that really requires process change, and it takes a while.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And my last question as you mentioned, Chris, taking additional opportunities to grow the business through acquisition. Has the acquisition environment changed at all with the activities we're seeing from private equity and strategic buyers we have multip
componenttext: And my last question as you mentioned, Chris, taking additional opportunities to grow the business through acquisition. Has the acquisition environment changed at all with the activities we're seeing from private equity and strategic buyers we have multiples got out of hand? Or how are you looking at the acquisition environment to date relative to maybe a year ago?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think they're certainly more activity as sellers no see on environment in the capital markets that will support transactions at more attractive levels, they hope. I think from our perspective, again, multiples are going to need to make sense for us to p
componenttext: I think they're certainly more activity as sellers no see on environment in the capital markets that will support transactions at more attractive levels, they hope. I think from our perspective, again, multiples are going to need to make sense for us to participate in an acquisition, right? So I don't think we've yet seen multiples runaway in any respects. I would say that it is more activity as a think sellers that have been wanting to sell but have had to wait for some period of time are now again more aggressively pursuing that possibility, just given the strength of the capital markets.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we have another question from Carla Casella from JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we have another question from Carla Casella from JPMorgan.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess can you give us a sense of how much of your education best today is in the higher education versus the K-12, and how you see that balance adjusting over time?
componenttext: I guess can you give us a sense of how much of your education best today is in the higher education versus the K-12, and how you see that balance adjusting over time?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's predominantly Higher Ed. So that's a combined business that is pushing $3 billion overall, and more than 2/3 of that is going to be in the Higher Ed sector. And Higher Ed is a higher margin subsector compared to K-12, so it is much more prominen
componenttext: Yes, it's predominantly Higher Ed. So that's a combined business that is pushing $3 billion overall, and more than 2/3 of that is going to be in the Higher Ed sector. And Higher Ed is a higher margin subsector compared to K-12, so it is much more prominent and important within the education vertical. Again, we've had a terrific performance really over the long period of time in the Higher Ed business, growing, as we talked a lot about, growing the base within the existing accounts by capturing more and more of the spend from that on-campus population. We've continued to do that. I think over the last 12 or 18 months, we've had a renewed focus and increased investment in the new sales resources within the business. And that fruit for us in fiscal '10. We has a very strong sales year and that certainly contributed to the growth we saw in Q1. K-12, it was a very nice quarter. We've talked about K-12 over the last couple of years as having some retention. It had a strong retention year in 2010 and a very strong new sales year, and so it's a very nice to see it contributed to the education sector's growth. And as I said earlier, the pipeline and really the size of the opportunity over time in converting market in K-12 is quite significant.
