headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the ARAMARK Corporation First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Chris Holland, Senior Vice President and Treasurer. Please proceed, Chris.
componenttext: Good afternoon, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen, to the ARAMARK Corporation First Quarter 2011 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Chris Holland, Senior Vice President and Treasurer. Please proceed, Chris.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and welcome to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our first quarter of fiscal 2011. Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will present an overview
componenttext:
Thank you, and welcome to ARAMARK Corporation's conference call to review the results of our first quarter of fiscal 2011. Here with me today is Fred Sutherland, our Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Fred and I will present an overview of our first quarter results and business operations, after which there will be an opportunity for phone-in participants to ask questions. I'd like to remind you that any recording or other use or transmission of this audio may not be done without the prior written consent of ARAMARK.
As we discuss the results for the quarter, you may want to refer to the Form 10-Q we filed earlier today, which contains our first quarter results for fiscal 2011. This Form 10-Q can be found on our website at www.aramark.com. In today's discussions of results, we mentioned certain non-GAAP financial measures. The Form 10-Q, as well as schedules we posted to our website earlier today, include reconciliations of these non-GAAP financial measures to the most comparable GAAP measures as required by SEC rules.
Our discussion of operating income during today's call will, in each instance, exclude the incremental intangibles amortization and property and equipment depreciation expense, resulting from the going-private transaction and the impact of stock option expense. These items are detailed in the schedules posted to our website before the call.
Various remarks that we may make in this call relating to matters that are not historical facts, including remarks about future expectations, anticipation, beliefs, estimates, plans and prospects constitute forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those expressed or implied as a result of various risks, uncertainties and important factors, including those discussed in the Risk Factors, MD&A and other sections of our Form 10-K and the Form 10-Q filed earlier today. We disclaim any duty to update or revise such forward-looking statements, whether as a result of future events or otherwise.
I'd like to now turn the program over to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter 2011 results call. As Chris said, I'd like to review our business and operating results, and then Chris will cover a few additional details of our performance for the quarter. Overall, w
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us for our first quarter 2011 results call. As Chris said, I'd like to review our business and operating results, and then Chris will cover a few additional details of our performance for the quarter. 
Overall, we were really quite pleased with our start for fiscal 2011. The economic environment remains somewhat uncertain, but the stability and signs of improvement we saw emerging late in 2010 had continued into our first fiscal quarter. Our efforts in recent quarters on driving operating efficiencies and more effectively managing our cost structure, together with benefits we're seeing from our new sales wins over the past 12 months, have helped us get off to a solid start for the year. While we remain cautious in our expectations for future economic growth and are not yet seeing signs of material improvement in employment levels, our balanced portfolio has and should continue to provide additional [indiscernible]. 
So now let me turn to our consolidated results for the quarter. We achieved sales of $3.3 billion, up 4% from the prior-year quarter on both in as-reported and organic growth basis. Operating income, which is adjusted to exclude the items Chris described earlier, increased 10% to $205 million. The impact of currency translation was minimal in the quarter. In our North American Food and Support Services segment, first quarter sales were up 4% also on a reported and organic basis to $2.3 billion, led primarily by Higher Education, K-12 and our Business and Industry group.
Our Business and Industry sector had sales increase at a mid-single digit rate, primarily from a solid base business growth in both food and facility services. During the first quarter, we did see a continuation of improved discretionary spending on the part of our corporate clients that started in late fiscal 2010, while employee population levels in most of our accounts remain relatively flat. While these trends are generally positive, we will likely need to have increasing employee populations within our client locations in order to generate sustained improvements on organic sales in the sector. The Education sector had low double digit growth, led by strong base business growth in the Higher Education, Food and Facilities business and excellent new business growth in K-12 food as a result of strong new sales year for the business in fiscal 2010.
In the Healthcare sector, sales grew in the low single digits, primarily as a result of solid base and new business growth in our Clinical Technology Services business. Our Sports and Entertainment sector had a sales decline at a high single digit rate, primarily due to the impact of prior year lost business and as well as significantly fewer Major League Baseball playoff games this year versus last year. Across our portfolio of stadiums and arenas, we have, in general, seemed somewhat improved levels of attendance and per capita spending in comparison to the prior year, although the results are, as always, further affected by individual team performance.
Adjusted operating income in the North American Food and Support Services segment increased 14% to $156 million, with higher Education and Healthcare delivering strong profit growth in the quarter. Results for the quarter include other income recognized related to a compensation agreement signed with the National Park Service, under which they agreed to pay down a portion of our investment in one of our concession contracts. And this other income contributed approximately six percentage points of the segment's growth for the quarter. As of this other income, profit and margin performance were still very solid in the quarter, reflecting the improved levels of organic sales growth, the strength of our Higher Education business, which has particular prominence in our first fiscal quarter, as well as our efforts to continue to efficiently manage our cost structure. 
Now turning to our International Food and Support Services segment. First quarter sales of $672 million were up 6% on both a reported and organic basis. Strong sales growth in many of our countries, particularly Germany and in South America, more than offset negative organic growth in the U.K. and Ireland. We also saw especially strong sales growth in China, which benefited from our operations at the Asian Games during the quarter. First quarter adjusted operating income was $15.4 million compared to $24.4 million in the prior year, with Germany and Japan delivering solid profit performance in the quarter. 
Now included in the results for the quarter was approximately $7 million of expenses related to efficiency and cost-reduction initiatives, including severance charges taken across several of our country operations. The comparison to the prior year is also negatively affected by, as we mentioned last year, the continuing challenging operating environment in the U.K., as well as approximately $2.6 million in VAT income that was recorded in the first quarter of fiscal 2010.
In our Uniform and Career Apparel segment, first quarter sales of $384 million were up 1% from a year ago, primarily driven by improved sales performance at Galls. The segment's overall organic sales growth was comparable to the reported increase. The Uniform business which, as you know, is sensitive to employment levels, and while we are continuing to see headcount stability among our clients, we ultimately need to see growth in employment among our clients for this segment to begin to generate materially improved levels of sales performance. Therefore, our sales outlook for this segment will remain cautious until we see signs of meaningful and sustained employment growth.
In the meantime, our team is focused to continue to drive efficiencies throughout the business and aggressively manage our cost structure while delivering quality service to our clients and customers. Price competition remains difficult, but we will continue to be disciplined as we sign new business and seek to retain profitable business.
Uniform segment adjusted operating income was $42 million, up 30% from $32.4 million in the year-ago quarter. About half of the year-over-year profit increase was due to a reduction in insurance reserves due to favorable claims experienced, resulting from our strong safety programs and improving safety performance. Adjusting for this item, profit results were still strong, reflecting the full realization of operating efficiencies from the integration of our Direct Marketing business, which we completed last year, our continued focus and driving cost efficiencies across the rental operations and improved profit performance at Galls.
Corporate expenses, adjusted to exclude the items that Chris described earlier, were $8.2 million in the quarter compared to $7.1 million in the year-ago quarter, primarily as a result of expenses associated with cost reduction and efficiency initiatives, which will benefit future quarters.
So at this point, let me turn it back over to Chris from some additional details.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Fred. I'd like to make a few comments on our capital structure and cash flow. We are pleased that for the trailing 12 months ending December 31, 2010, our adjusted EBITDA increased to $1.051 billion, up from $1.036 billion at October 1, 2010. Inte
componenttext:
Thanks, Fred. I'd like to make a few comments on our capital structure and cash flow. We are pleased that for the trailing 12 months ending December 31, 2010, our adjusted EBITDA increased to $1.051 billion, up from $1.036 billion at October 1, 2010. Interest and other financing costs were $109.1 million for the first quarter level with the year-ago quarter's expense. 
Approximately 75% of our debt portfolio is at fixed interest rates, and our overall weighted average cost of debt at quarter end was approximately 6.5%. Total reported debt at the end of the quarter was $5.779 billion. Our secured debt, as defined in our credit agreement, totaled $3.47 billion, including a term loan balance of $3.296 billion and a revolver balance of $129 million. Our $250 million accounts receivable securitization facility was also fully utilized as of quarter end. 
Beginning in fiscal 2011, new accounting guidance changed the way we record our accounts receivable facility on a prospective basis. The funding under this facility is now accounted for as a secured borrowing and not a sale of receivables and, as such, is reflected in our total reported debt balance of $5.779 billion. The funding has always been included as part of our secured and total debt calculations under our senior secured credit agreement and as described in prior quarterly calls and various analyst conference presentations, so there's no change to any of these calculations. While this change is cash flow neutral, it is reflected on the cash flow statement as a use of cash in operating activities and a source of cash in financing activities during fiscal 2011.
We continue to enjoy a strong liquidity position. And as of quarter end, we had approximately $450 million of available borrowing capacity under our revolving credit facility. Based on our growth and trailing EBITDA and lowered debt levels compared to the same quarter last year, our secured debt ratio improved to 3.47x as of December 31 compared to 3.70x at the end of the year-ago quarter.
Net capital expenditures for the quarter were $54 million compared to $58 million in the prior-year quarter, as we continue to maintain a disciplined approach as we evaluate and invest in new opportunities. For the full year, we would expect that net capital expenditures would be somewhat higher than prior-year levels. 
And finally, consistent with historical patterns, working capital was a use of cash for us during the first quarter and was in line with our expectations. As we have previously mentioned, for the full year of fiscal 2011, we anticipate that working capital will be a more typical use of cash for us overall. 
Now let me turn the call back to Fred.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris. Considering the still uncertain economic environment, we are pleased with our solid overall performance during the first quarter and with our start to fiscal 2011. Both our top and bottom line performance has improved sequentially as we con
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris. Considering the still uncertain economic environment, we are pleased with our solid overall performance during the first quarter and with our start to fiscal 2011. Both our top and bottom line performance has improved sequentially as we continue to see stability in our cyclical businesses and more typically solid performance in our other sectors. While we remain cautious given the still unclear outlook for employment growth, we are benefiting from a portfolio of sectors, geographies and clients that provides us with a good balance overall. We also have and will maintain a heightened focus on managing our cost and cash flow as we move through 2011.
Having come to a very challenging environment in recent years, we continue to be quite excited about the longer-term growth opportunities we see as we look across our portfolio of businesses and sectors. In addition, we also have a more efficient cost structure now, and we are continuing to look for ways to further improve the efficiency and the effectiveness of our operations. 
So thank you, again, for your time this afternoon and for your continued support of ARAMARK. And at this point, we'd be happy to take your questions.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Karru Martinson from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Karru Martinson from Deutsche Bank.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: In terms of the pricing competition that you're seeing, I'm wondering how does that fit in with what we're reading about a higher input cost in raw materials? And what's your view on gross margins going forward?
componenttext: In terms of the pricing competition that you're seeing, I'm wondering how does that fit in with what we're reading about a higher input cost in raw materials? And what's your view on gross margins going forward?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: This is Fred. Let me answer that business separately, with respect to the Food and Facilities business and the Uniform business. In the Food and Facilities business, we actually have a fair amount of flexibility in the menus that we offer and how we move
componenttext: This is Fred. Let me answer that business separately, with respect to the Food and Facilities business and the Uniform business. In the Food and Facilities business, we actually have a fair amount of flexibility in the menus that we offer and how we move items on the menu from one week to the next, and we can do that in response to differential increases in various food items. The overall food cost inflation that we're seeing right now year-over-year is in the range of about 3%. So while it's clearly up from where it was a while ago, it's still very manageable. And increasingly, in the Food business, greater and greater percentage of our sales are really direct to the consumer, to the user, so we typically have pricing flexibility there and it doesn't involve negotiation with the client. With respect to the Uniform business, we are seeing increases in raw material prices, fabric prices, particularly cotton. And I think everybody has read about that. It's been written about with respect to the retail clothing industry. And there again, just as we did with fuel cost a few years ago, which are also up somewhat year-over-year by the way, I mean something that's generally known throughout the markets in which we compete. And we've developed a pretty specific pricing increase strategies so that we can recapture a good portion, if not all of those, cost increases and we go and talk to our customers. They certainly understand what we're talking about and don't disagree with the issue. So we think that both of those are things that we can navigate or we're hopeful that we can.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And you guys have been successful in terms of taking cost out of the business in creating kind of that more efficient cost structure that you referenced. I mean, how much more room do you feel is there to take cost out?
componenttext: And you guys have been successful in terms of taking cost out of the business in creating kind of that more efficient cost structure that you referenced. I mean, how much more room do you feel is there to take cost out?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Actually, we feel there's a fair amount of additional room and the room comes from more systematic operation of the businesses, both the Food, Facilities business and the Uniform business and more standardization of process with regard to labor management
componenttext: Actually, we feel there's a fair amount of additional room and the room comes from more systematic operation of the businesses, both the Food, Facilities business and the Uniform business and more standardization of process with regard to labor management and food cost management. And that is a multiyear project that we think we'll continue to benefit us for some time.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Micah Kaplan from Bank of America.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Micah Kaplan from Bank of America.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess the last couple of quarters, the sales growth is not quite as good as this quarter, but it seem pretty good. But you had I guess and especially in the Healthcare you mentioned some of the margin compression issues. So it seems like obviously the m
componenttext: I guess the last couple of quarters, the sales growth is not quite as good as this quarter, but it seem pretty good. But you had I guess and especially in the Healthcare you mentioned some of the margin compression issues. So it seems like obviously the margins were better this quarter. I mean, do you feel like you're lapping out on a year-over-year basis and you're mostly through some of those concessions? Or how would you characterize that at this point?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we talked about Healthcare the last several quarters. We did about, the middle part of last year, make some changes to the cost infrastructure within that business, which we're benefiting from now. And also, as we have talked about needing to
componenttext: Yes, I think we talked about Healthcare the last several quarters. We did about, the middle part of last year, make some changes to the cost infrastructure within that business, which we're benefiting from now. And also, as we have talked about needing to help existing clients through challenging budgetary situations, I think the team has gotten much more adept at managing those discussions in a way that we're able to maintain levels of profitability through, again, capturing or helping clients reduce costs in other areas where we may have not been servicing them yet. And so I think it's a combination of the business having a much better cost structure and one that's more appropriate for the current environment, as well as the teams in the field much more proactively, aggressively and I think adeptly dealing with these case-by-case situations where existing clients are again trying to work through still challenging budgetary environments. So I think we feel certainly better about the business sitting here today, and feel good about how we think it'll perform the balance of the year.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And is that still primarily or even if you're passing out, is it still primarily a healthcare issue? Or does that seep into some of the other portions of your business?
componenttext: And is that still primarily or even if you're passing out, is it still primarily a healthcare issue? Or does that seep into some of the other portions of your business?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Again, I think where it's seeped in and we talked about this for a while, is in those parts of the economy and primarily in the public sector, we are seeing very significant sales pipelines where still self-operated school districts, correctional faciliti
componenttext: Again, I think where it's seeped in and we talked about this for a while, is in those parts of the economy and primarily in the public sector, we are seeing very significant sales pipelines where still self-operated school districts, correctional facilities, public sector hospitals, et cetera are increasingly looking at outsourcing as a way to help them deal with what's a challenging environment today and one that sounds like it's going to be with us for a while. So I think Healthcare is I think reasonably unique in that regard, but across a number of those sectors, we continue to see very good opportunities on the new business side.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And I guess just a cleanup, it looks like in the EBITDA in what you guys call your covenant EBITDA, I guess you have to gain from the National Park Services backed out, but is the risk insurance benefit is that included in the current $305 million EBITDA
componenttext: And I guess just a cleanup, it looks like in the EBITDA in what you guys call your covenant EBITDA, I guess you have to gain from the National Park Services backed out, but is the risk insurance benefit is that included in the current $305 million EBITDA number that you guys are showing?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it is and think about that -- I mean that is insurance-related expenses that we've incurred in the past really in support of a lot of the programs on the safety side that are bearing fruit. And so they are real savings we're realizing and frankly, we
componenttext: Yes, it is and think about that -- I mean that is insurance-related expenses that we've incurred in the past really in support of a lot of the programs on the safety side that are bearing fruit. And so they are real savings we're realizing and frankly, we feel good about our ability to continue to generate improved safety performance over time that are really result in lower insurance, lower claims, et cetera. So that amount, which is in the $5 million range, just to put a number on it, is not backed out of adjusted EBITDA.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then just lastly, you guys are obviously chipping away the debt here. I mean, just given kind of more where the high-yield market is, I mean is it potentially putting additional debt on the structures, is that at least kind of on the table at this poi
componenttext: And then just lastly, you guys are obviously chipping away the debt here. I mean, just given kind of more where the high-yield market is, I mean is it potentially putting additional debt on the structures, is that at least kind of on the table at this point in terms of how you guys think about your potential strategic options here?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think as we've talked about for a long time, we're trying to manage the capital structure prudently. We'll continue to do that. As we've talked about, we are and have always been looking at acquisitions that we think will strengthen the company. We
componenttext: Yes, I think as we've talked about for a long time, we're trying to manage the capital structure prudently. We'll continue to do that. As we've talked about, we are and have always been looking at acquisitions that we think will strengthen the company. We want to maintain flexibility to do that. And again, in considering other alternatives, the key focus for us is continuing to maintain a capital structure that allow us to move the company forward, invest in strategic opportunities and as we've talked over time, improve the credit profile of the company over time.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And our following question comes from Bryan Hunt from Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: And our following question comes from Bryan Hunt from Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: You mentioned, Chris, a little bit about new contract opportunities. Could you talk about retention rate for the quarter and what other -- you all picked up any new contract wins during the period?
componenttext: You mentioned, Chris, a little bit about new contract opportunities. Could you talk about retention rate for the quarter and what other -- you all picked up any new contract wins during the period?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Retention rates were on plan and very consistent with prior year, so no issues there. And as we look out across the rest of the year, we're focused on achieving again a retention target that is in the mid-90% range. We had a good new sales quarter and bot
componenttext: Retention rates were on plan and very consistent with prior year, so no issues there. And as we look out across the rest of the year, we're focused on achieving again a retention target that is in the mid-90% range. We had a good new sales quarter and both our gross new sales and our net new sales are up compared to the prior year in the quarter. And we've got again good wins in Healthcare, Higher Ed, across a number of our countries, Germany and Chile, where we've seen strong growth on the back of the Mining business. We've continue to generate good rates of new business. And as I mentioned, a good pipeline in sectors like corrections and K-12, which we think will bear fruit over the course of the year.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Based on the organic sales growth you all saw on the quarter of little over 4%, is that reflective of the run rate of your new wins? Or should we expect an accelerated top line?
componenttext: Based on the organic sales growth you all saw on the quarter of little over 4%, is that reflective of the run rate of your new wins? Or should we expect an accelerated top line?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, the thing about Q1 that we always like to caution you about is the Higher Ed business, which had again a very strong quarter is a attractive margin business for us. And as Fred said, the Education sector grew low double digits for us. It's very promi
componenttext: Yes, the thing about Q1 that we always like to caution you about is the Higher Ed business, which had again a very strong quarter is a attractive margin business for us. And as Fred said, the Education sector grew low double digits for us. It's very prominent in the first quarter, much less prominent in the second and third quarter. And that business, both K-12 and Higher Ed, had good new sales years last year. That's all reflected in Q1, but it just doesn't represent itself the same way in Q2 and Q3, so that impacts the mix of growth. As we look out over the quarter, we would expect to see comparable levels of growth. And again, the new business wins in some of the sectors that occurred during the course of the year only really represent them in the financials in the beginning of Q4 in the Education business and K-12 business. And so again, we'll see what the economy does. But in general, I would caution you against thinking that you'd see continued acceleration of organic growth as we move into the second quarter.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then shifting gears and looking at the cost line item. Fred, you mentioned about the levers you have to deal with food inflation in terms of adjusting pricing directly to the consumer and adjusting menu mix. Do you feel like those levers are less in t
componenttext: And then shifting gears and looking at the cost line item. Fred, you mentioned about the levers you have to deal with food inflation in terms of adjusting pricing directly to the consumer and adjusting menu mix. Do you feel like those levers are less in this environment than they way three years ago when we saw significant food inflation? Or could you talk about maybe what you're doing different today versus three years ago?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I think actually the levers are pretty much the same, and we're really following the same procedures that we followed before. I think we're probably a little more effective and a little more quicker and a little more standardized on how we roll them
componenttext: Well, I think actually the levers are pretty much the same, and we're really following the same procedures that we followed before. I think we're probably a little more effective and a little more quicker and a little more standardized on how we roll them out. Because that overall function increasingly is led by a central operation in terms of menu engineering and planning. And of course, we've always had a centralized supply chain function. So I'd say those tools are just as effective as they were before. And of course before, we were saying at one point I think it peaked out inflation rates were probably high single digits year-over-year. So as I mentioned earlier, our inflation is up clearly over the last three to six months, but it's way short of where it was a few years ago, as you point out.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think the other point, the environment it's a lot more stable when we think about the end of our fiscal '08, at the time of the Lehman bankruptcy and the uncertainty in the environment. Clearly, our clients we're in a different mindset than they are tod
componenttext: I think the other point, the environment it's a lot more stable when we think about the end of our fiscal '08, at the time of the Lehman bankruptcy and the uncertainty in the environment. Clearly, our clients we're in a different mindset than they are today. So I think the conversations and the ability to move through price increases is somewhat easier today, just given I think what's a much more stable environment and a more stable mindset that both the clients and consumers have vis-à-vis again late 2008.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: You also mentioned, Fred, that pulling cost out of the business has been a way you're dealing with some of this inflation. Is there a way you can quantify for us maybe how much cost you pulled out of the business last year, and then maybe with some of you
componenttext: You also mentioned, Fred, that pulling cost out of the business has been a way you're dealing with some of this inflation. Is there a way you can quantify for us maybe how much cost you pulled out of the business last year, and then maybe with some of your severance and restructuring charges you took in Q1, what you're looking for in terms of cost savings for this year?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Well, I can say that it's in the over the entire organization certainly in the tens of millions of dollars. And I think in terms of making the overhead structure, the above-the-unit structure more effective, we've accomplished a lot of that, not that ther
componenttext: Well, I can say that it's in the over the entire organization certainly in the tens of millions of dollars. And I think in terms of making the overhead structure, the above-the-unit structure more effective, we've accomplished a lot of that, not that there isn't more opportunity. We're more focused really in over the longer term is that the unit level in improving our food cost percentage and improving our labor cost percentage. [indiscernible] through systems at thousands and thousands of locations. And so that's something that really requires process change and it takes a while.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Now when you said tens of millions, was that over last year? Or is that something...
componenttext: Now when you said tens of millions, was that over last year? Or is that something...

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Over the last several years.
componenttext: Over the last several years.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: You mentioned, Chris, taking additional opportunities to grow the business through acquisition. Has the acquisition environment changed at all with the activities we're seeing from private equity and strategic buyers have the multiples got out of hand? Or
componenttext: You mentioned, Chris, taking additional opportunities to grow the business through acquisition. Has the acquisition environment changed at all with the activities we're seeing from private equity and strategic buyers have the multiples got out of hand? Or how are you all looking at the acquisition environment today relative to maybe a year ago?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I think there are certainly more activity as sellers I think now you see in environment and the capital markets that will support transactions at more attractive levels, they hope. I think from our perspective, again, multiples are going to need to make s
componenttext: I think there are certainly more activity as sellers I think now you see in environment and the capital markets that will support transactions at more attractive levels, they hope. I think from our perspective, again, multiples are going to need to make sense for us to participate in an acquisition, right? So I don't think we've yet seen multiples run away in any respects. I would say that it is more activity as I think sellers that have been wanting to sell, but have had to wait for some period of time are now again more aggressively pursuing that possibility, just given the strength of the capital markets.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we have another question from Carla Casella from JPMorgan.
componenttext: And we have another question from Carla Casella from JPMorgan.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I guess can you give us a sense for how much of your Education business today is in the Higher Education versus the K-12, and how you see that balance adjusting over time?
componenttext: I guess can you give us a sense for how much of your Education business today is in the Higher Education versus the K-12, and how you see that balance adjusting over time?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's predominantly Higher Ed. So that's a combined business that is pushing $3 billion overall and more than 2/3 of that is going to be in the Higher Ed sector. And Higher Ed is a higher margin subsector compared to K-12, so it is much more prominent
componenttext: Yes, it's predominantly Higher Ed. So that's a combined business that is pushing $3 billion overall and more than 2/3 of that is going to be in the Higher Ed sector. And Higher Ed is a higher margin subsector compared to K-12, so it is much more prominent and important within the education vertical. Again, we've had terrific performance really over the long period of time in the Higher Ed business, growing, as we talked a lot about, just growing in the base within the existing accounts by capturing more and more of the spend from that on-campus population. We've continued to do that. I think over the last 12 or 18 months, we've had a renewed focus and an increased investment in the new sales resources within the business and that paid fruit for us in fiscal '10. We had a very strong sales year and that's certainly contributed to the growth we saw in Q1. K-12, it was a very nice quarter. We've talked about K-12 over the last couple of years as having some retention challenges. It had a strong retention year in 2010 and a very strong new sales year, and so it's very nice to see it contributing to the education sector's growth. And as I said earlier, the pipeline and really the size of the opportunity over time in converting the self-op part of the market in K-12 we think is quite significant.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And just to add to that, there clearly is a significant pressure, as we all know, on various municipalities and other governmental entities that are in the Schools business. And we think that, that might put some pressure on our existing relationships. We
componenttext: And just to add to that, there clearly is a significant pressure, as we all know, on various municipalities and other governmental entities that are in the Schools business. And we think that, that might put some pressure on our existing relationships. We think net-net, given the fact that, as Chris said, the significant majority of the overall market is self-operated and that we have a very balanced capability actually and base of business between Food and Facilities in K-12. That there's real very interesting long-term opportunity there, given all of those circumstances.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And we have a question from Reza Vahabzadeh from Barclays Capital.
componenttext: And we have a question from Reza Vahabzadeh from Barclays Capital.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Obviously, we've spoken about the Higher Education business and it's been a successful business for you in the past, but the rate of growth in this quarter was certainly above last couple of years. Anything unique going on in terms of the winning share of
componenttext: Obviously, we've spoken about the Higher Education business and it's been a successful business for you in the past, but the rate of growth in this quarter was certainly above last couple of years. Anything unique going on in terms of the winning share of the pie in this quarter? Or was there any changes in number of service days, any kind of color that you can provide on that?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, as I've mentioned, historically, we've really relied on base business growth as the predominant contributor. Clearly, the business was somewhat impacted by the recession, like every part of the economy. And so the retail portion of that business, we
componenttext: Yes, as I've mentioned, historically, we've really relied on base business growth as the predominant contributor. Clearly, the business was somewhat impacted by the recession, like every part of the economy. And so the retail portion of that business, we saw come under a little bit of pressure through the depths of the recession. We've seen some better performance there. And as I said, 2010 was a very strong, I think historically strong new business year for Higher Ed, again on the back of us making some strategic investments in new business resources. So the contribution from new business in the quarter was certainly much higher than it was in the year-ago quarter.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And as far as the B&I sector, it seems like this quarter was one of the better quarters in recent times. Is that due to populations? Or is that due to spend per person? Any color on the B&I segment?
componenttext: And as far as the B&I sector, it seems like this quarter was one of the better quarters in recent times. Is that due to populations? Or is that due to spend per person? Any color on the B&I segment?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's not due to employment increases or population increases in any significant way. So it's due to a combination of an increase per capita or consumer spending, because increasingly these operations are retail operations. And then secondly, it is due to
componenttext: It's not due to employment increases or population increases in any significant way. So it's due to a combination of an increase per capita or consumer spending, because increasingly these operations are retail operations. And then secondly, it is due to our corporate clients loosening the purse strings with respect to meeting, catering, events and that sort of thing.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then on Sports and I guess Entertainment side, is that mostly due to losses from prior year? Or can you recover from some of these losses in the coming year?
componenttext: And then on Sports and I guess Entertainment side, is that mostly due to losses from prior year? Or can you recover from some of these losses in the coming year?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: It's actually predominantly related to a loss a couple of years ago, the new Meadowlands is an account that we do not operate. We did operate the old Meadowlands that was a contract that again was awarded to somebody else a couple of years ago. It's just
componenttext: It's actually predominantly related to a loss a couple of years ago, the new Meadowlands is an account that we do not operate. We did operate the old Meadowlands that was a contract that again was awarded to somebody else a couple of years ago. It's just that we're now doing feeling it for the first time, as well as some convention center losses frankly, that were profitable last year. So it's really the impact of those losses that you're seeing in the growth rate. And so again, we plan for them. We knew about them. We've known about them for quite some time. The base in general is more stable, as Fred had said. But clearly, new business in that sector is much more spotty, just given the nature of the industry. So nothing unusual or surprising to us in the quarter, it was exactly what we expected.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And as you would expect, we're talking about the NFL, that the impact of that loss is particularly acute in the first quarter and the other thing we mentioned was Major League Baseball playoff games. And I believe the decline in Sports and Entertainment,
componenttext: And as you would expect, we're talking about the NFL, that the impact of that loss is particularly acute in the first quarter and the other thing we mentioned was Major League Baseball playoff games. And I believe the decline in Sports and Entertainment, close to half of it, are simply due to a lower number of Major League playoff games for our teams this year versus last year.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Are you cycling, have you fully lapped against the lost of Meadowlands then this quarter?
componenttext: Are you cycling, have you fully lapped against the lost of Meadowlands then this quarter?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then the same question regarding the U.K. B&I sector, have you finally bottomed out in that business segment?
componenttext: And then the same question regarding the U.K. B&I sector, have you finally bottomed out in that business segment?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the contracts we had talked about we are now lapped. Now that environment continues to not be a great environment, as you know. So we still have the challenges with respect to operating in a pressured situation, but we've lapped the big B&I l
componenttext: Yes, I think the contracts we had talked about we are now lapped. Now that environment continues to not be a great environment, as you know. So we still have the challenges with respect to operating in a pressured situation, but we've lapped the big B&I losses we had talked about last year. We've now lapped.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And then your CapEx guidance for this year, I know you talked about it in the last quarter, but would it be about the same as the 2009 or just somewhat higher than 2010?
componenttext: And then your CapEx guidance for this year, I know you talked about it in the last quarter, but would it be about the same as the 2009 or just somewhat higher than 2010?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think just somewhat higher than 2010.
componenttext: Yes, I think just somewhat higher than 2010.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011

componenttext: And our next question comes from Ben Senten [ph] from Oak Hill Advisors.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: It was 6%.
componenttext: It was 6%.

componenttext: And our last question comes from Karen Eltrich from Goldman Sachs.

componenttext: Getting back to the pricing, as we look at the revenue growth that we saw this quarter, was any of that pricing? And I say that because I did notice that you raised pricing on our sodas here?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And getting back to the Higher Ed, as you mentioned, the focus on same-store sales. How much has restaurant franchising played a factor in growing comp store sales getting more variety on campus? And how many franchises do you have at this point?
componenttext: And getting back to the Higher Ed, as you mentioned, the focus on same-store sales. How much has restaurant franchising played a factor in growing comp store sales getting more variety on campus? And how many franchises do you have at this point?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: I mean hundreds of franchises across the portfolio. I think there's 85 Starbucks on campuses that we're now running. I can't comment off the top of my head on the exact number of franchises, but it's certainly across the portfolio. It's hundreds. And agai
componenttext: I mean hundreds of franchises across the portfolio. I think there's 85 Starbucks on campuses that we're now running. I can't comment off the top of my head on the exact number of franchises, but it's certainly across the portfolio. It's hundreds. And again, it's really part of the mix. We try to provide an offering and a choice to the students that's going to maximize their satisfaction and maximize the economics to us in the university. And so it's a combination of our brands and national brands where we think that mix will drive the best outcome. So again, in a more urban environment where they've got many more choices right out the door, national brands may make a lot more sense in more rural environments where they're pretty landlocked to the campus. You're more likely to have as good success with our brands, and so it's really just finding the right mix. But both are important in terms of supporting how we'll grow in the business.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And our overall retail sales on a sector like that are not -- the national brands are important, but they're not dominant.
componenttext: And our overall retail sales on a sector like that are not -- the national brands are important, but they're not dominant.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: And what are some of the national brands that you tend to partner with, that actually you get the best results with, besides obviously Starbucks.
componenttext: And what are some of the national brands that you tend to partner with, that actually you get the best results with, besides obviously Starbucks.

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Chick-fil-A is a very popular franchise for us and we've got -- again, I think it will depend on the geography. Subway is another one that we have a lot of success with. And again, we've got everything in the portfolio, and I'm sure there's examples and l
componenttext: Chick-fil-A is a very popular franchise for us and we've got -- again, I think it will depend on the geography. Subway is another one that we have a lot of success with. And again, we've got everything in the portfolio, and I'm sure there's examples and locations where each have helped drive good growth.

componenttext: And we do have a follow-up question from Reza Vahabzadeh from Barclays Capital.

componenttext: Yes, I'm sorry if I missed this, but on the Healthcare sector front, are those competitive pressures that you've highlighted in the past are those continuing? And have you been able to generate enough cost savings to offset that?

headline: ARAMARK Corporation, Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Feb 09, 2011
componenttextpreview: Yes, actually, somebody had asked that earlier, and we are managing through it in a much better way than a year ago. And again, in addition to have a better cost structure overall, which is helping the results. As we talked about towards the back end of l
componenttext: Yes, actually, somebody had asked that earlier, and we are managing through it in a much better way than a year ago. And again, in addition to have a better cost structure overall, which is helping the results. As we talked about towards the back end of last year, having the teams again have more proactively discussions with clients do help them deal with budgetary pressures in ways that don't just include us reducing our fee or reducing our margin. We've been much more successful and proactive at leading the conversations in a way that we've been able to retain margin and retain profit. The pressure is still there. I think the pressure will be there in that sector for quite some time, but I think we're much more comfortable and we can manage through it.
